subject: SOCW
title: Introduction to the Social Work Experience
description: An introduction to the profession of social work, its historical roots, its values, and its fields of practice. Topics include the field of social work, social welfare policy, social work values and ethics, the social work knowledge base, career opportunities in various fields of social work, and current issues in social work. A minimum of 30 supervised volunteer hours in an approved social service setting are required. Furthermore, this class delves into topics related to social, racial, economic, and environmental justice. Every semester.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Special Projects
prerequisites: Department Head approval.
description: Individual or group projects. Maximum credit 4 hours. On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Introduction to Social Policy: A Social Justice Perspective
prerequisites: SOCW 1100 is preferred but not required
description: This is an introduction to the social policy in the United States as it relates to the welfare of both children and families. This course will provide an overview of multiple policies related to children and families, theories related to understanding and implementing public policy, and an overview of the development, implementation, and evaluation of policy. Prerequisites: SOCW 1100 is preferred but not required. General Education Category: Behavioral and Social Science
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Interviewing Skills
description: Interviewing skills is a required pre-social work course where students develop communication, and technical skills for the professional interview. Students cultivate self-awareness and self-regulation for work with diverse populations and demonstrate empathy, interpersonal and technical interviewing skills to effectively engage and assess clients.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Matters of Ethnicity, Race, Class and Gender
description: This diversity course examines matters of class, ethnicity, gender and race relations from a multicultural perspective. Contemporary issues along the diversity continuum such as gender inequality, diversity in religion and minority groups, immigration, and social justice are also explored. Fall and Spring semesters. General Education Category: Behavioral and Social Science
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Group Studies
prerequisites: Department Head approval
description: On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval. Department may have additional prerequisite requirements.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
description: Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families explores various strategies for designing and implementing social work engagement, assessment, intervention, and evaluation with individual and family clients. Students will develop generalist practice skills such as interviewing skills, active listening, building rapport and problem-solving. Students will apply social work values, ethics and relevant theoretical perspectives through an anti-racist, anti- oppressive lense to work effectively with diverse individual and family clients. Fall semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Social Work Practice with Groups
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
description: Social Work Practice with Groups explores knowledge, values, and skills for working with diverse groups in the context of a social work setting. Students will develop an understanding of the needs of at-risk and oppressed populations, apply social work values and ethics in decision-making, and practice problem-solving and assessment skills needed for working within a group setting. Students will also develop the skills and knowledge for forming and leading groups. This class will help prepare students to conduct themselves effectively with diverse client populations, in varying community settings, and with a variety of client issues or concerns. Spring semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Professionalism in Social Work Practice I
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work Program or Department Head approval
description: This course if the first of a two course sequence in the BSW foundation year. It offers students the opportunity to use self-reflection to examine their attitudes and aptitudes toward a career in social work. It also encourages and promotes evaluation of concurrent social work classes from an intrapersonal as well as an academic perspective. Students will enhance core qualities such as self-knowledge, critical thinking and communication skills and the ability to engage diverse clients from an anti-oppressive, anti-racist lens. Students will also begin developing knowledge in leadership principles in social work. Fall semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work Program or Department Head approval. source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga23.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment I
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
description: This course builds on essential knowledge, values, and skills related to social work theory and micro social work practice. This course emphasizes systems, person-in-environment perspective and a social, economic, racial, and political justice framework. Relevant concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences will be explored with the aim of providing students with a holistic view of human behavior, specifically with individuals and families. This contextual emphasis will look at human development in the context of larger social conflicts associated with class, race, ethnicity, sex and gender identity, sexual orientation, and disability. Within this context, there is a focus on theories, models, conceptual frameworks, and evidence-based practice that pertain to working with individuals and families. There is also an emphasis on knowledge, skills, values, and cognitive affective processes that are explicitly or implicitly involved in social work practice within a micro context. Fall semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Child Welfare I
prerequisites: SOCW 1100 or any Sociology, Psychology or Anthropology course or Department Head approval.
description: This is the first in a series of two child welfare courses offered as part of the Tennessee Child Welfare Certification Program. The course introduces students to knowledge of child maltreatment and the juvenile justice system. It provides an overview of the child welfare system describing the history, policies, and programs, both state and federal. Fall semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 1100 or any Sociology, Psychology or Anthropology course or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Mental Health Perspectives
prerequisites: Any Sociology, Psychology, or Anthropology course or Department Head approval.
description: This course provides a foundational understanding of mental health conditions and criteria. Students will acquire relevant knowledge and skills to inform a human rights perspective, cultural humility, and an anti-oppressive approach to mental health social work services. The course will specifically focus on inequities in mental health access, service delivery and utilization. On demand. Prerequisites: Any Sociology, Psychology, or Anthropology course or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Diversity and Culturally Grounded Social Work
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
description: This required social work core course is designed to increase student knowledge, understanding, and awareness of issues related to human rights and social justice. This course also provides content that focuses on important concepts and theoretical frameworks related to diversity, equity, inclusion and an anti-racism and an anti-oppressive social work practice approach in service delivery. Fall semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Social Work Healthcare Services and Policies
prerequisites: SOCW 3060 and SOCW 3120 or Department Head approval.
description: This course provides a basic understanding of social work practice in medical and health-related settings. Emphasis is placed on interdisciplinary practice, diverse skills, roles, and functions of social workers in health care. Students are given an overview of current health policy and the impact of local, state, and federal policy on delivery of services. On demand. Prerequisites: SOCW 3060 and SOCW 3120 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment II
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
description: This course is the second of a two semester Human Behavior and the Social Environment sequence. This course focuses on a contextual emphasis, which looks at human development in the context of larger social conflicts associated with class, race, ethnicity, sex and gender identity, sexual orientation, and disability status with underlying themes of diversity, understanding marginalization, and social, racial economic, and environmental justice. Spring semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Introduction to Applied Research and Professional Writing
prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
description: This class introduces research methods and statistics, with particular attention to examples from Social Work research. Using examples, students become familiar with the whole of the research process from the identification of the problem to the presentation of results. Students will be exposed to the full range of alternative research designs, including both quantitative and qualitative research methods. Students will critically evaluate research design and scientific evidence and discuss the ethical concerns and potential bias of a research using a culturally informed, anti-racist and anti- oppressive perspective. Students will also develop professional writing skills in APA style through various writing assignments. Spring semester. Prerequisites: Admission into the Social Work program or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Group Studies
prerequisites: Department Head approval
description: On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval. Department may have additional prerequisite requirements.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Social Work Practice with Communities and Organizations
prerequisites: SOCW 3420 with a minimum grade of a “C” or Department Head approval.
description: This course prepares students with knowledge and skills for practice within a broad array of community and organizational systems. This course emphasizes knowledge, theories, and frameworks relevant to community and organizational practice that are sensitive to human diversity, such as community development, social action, and organizing and planning. The course will help students develop knowledge, skills, and understand how to apply values when assessing and intervening within communities and organizations. Students will also reflect on cognitive/affective processes inherent to each student when interacting with diverse communities and organizations. Fall semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 3420 with a minimum grade of a “C” or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Professional Practice in Social Work II
prerequisites: SOCW 3060 , SOCW 3080 , SOCW 3120 and SOCW 3330 with a minimum grade of B or Department Head approval.
description: Professional Practice in Social Work is designed to assist social work students to build on a competency-based curriculum and begins the process of becoming skilled at demonstrating the professional use of self in preparation for Field Education. The application of self-assessment, the use of critical feedback and integrating competency-based knowledge and practice is emphasized. Spring semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 3060 , SOCW 3080 , SOCW 3120 and SOCW 3330 with a minimum grade of B or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Social Work Policy and Practice
prerequisites: Admission to the program or Department Head approval
description: This course is designed to develop analytical skills and the ability to engage in critical thinking concerning social welfare programs, policies, and social problems that create implications for policymaking at organizational and community system levels. Topics include the history of social reform in the social work profession, ethical reasoning in policy practice, policymaking in the US political system, and advocacy for human rights. Emphasis is also placed on critically assessing the appropriateness and adequacy of current social welfare policies within the context of social work practice and advocating for policies that advance human rights and social, racial, economic, and environmental justice. The course will expose students to various frameworks for understanding the strengths and limitations of policies, as well as incorporate a social, racial, economic, and environmental justice lens in analyzing, developing, and advocating for policy. Spring semester. Prerequisites: Admission to the program or Department Head approval. Social Work course fee will be assessed.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Field Education I
prerequisites: SOCW 3070 , SOCW 3420 , and SOCW 3760 with a grade of C or higher
description: This is the first course of the two-part Field Education experience. The course provides the opportunity for students to apply practice theory to develop skills for generalist social work practice. Through active participation in the social service delivery system, the student becomes familiar with agency structures, functions, and programs. Students are required to complete a minimum of 16 hours per week in an agency setting to accrue a total of 200 hours for the semester. Students will also develop and complete the comprehensive Field Learning Agreement to document their successful application of social work competencies and practice behaviors. Fall semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 3070 , SOCW 3420 , and SOCW 3760 with a grade of C or higher. Students will complete SOCW 4080 with a grade of B or higher, submit the Field Education application, and receive Field Director approval prior to entering Field Education. Corequisites: SOCW 4130 . Open to Social Work majors only. Social Work course fee will be assessed.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Integrative Field Seminar I
prerequisites: SOCW 3070 , SOCW 3420 , SOCW 3760 and SOCW 4080 or Department Head approval
description: This course is designed to provide a forum for providing mutual support, discussing and completing departmental assignments, exploring on-going practice concerns in the field practicum, and creating an arena in which peer learning takes place. Fall semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 3070 , SOCW 3420 , SOCW 3760 and SOCW 4080 or Department Head approval. Corequisites: SOCW 4120 .
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Applied Research
prerequisites: SOCW 3760 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval.
description: This course builds on the research knowledge and skills learned in previous coursework. Students will apply their knowledge about research methods and continue developing their research skills through either an individual or group- led senior research project, which many groups will conduct in partnership with a community social service agency. Throughout the course of the semester, students will conduct a comprehensive literature review and develop a research proposal based on their chosen research topics/questions, including developing data collection tools, and an IRB form. Students also need to have a thorough discussion about potential ethical concerns using a culturally informed, anti- racist, and anti-oppressive perspective. Fall semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 3760 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Child Welfare II
prerequisites: SOCW 3230 and Department Head approval
description: This is the second in a series of two courses offered as part of the Tennessee Child Welfare Certification Program. It is designed to assist students in acquiring the practice skills to become culturally competent child welfare workers. The course will analyze the practices of various human/social service agencies that provide services aimed at children, youth and families. Spring semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 3230 and Department Head approval. Open to child welfare certification and stipend BSW students only.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: School Social Work and the Law
prerequisites: SOCW 3060 and SOCW 3120 or Department Head approval.
description: This course provides an orientation to social work practice in the public school setting. It covers historical, legal, and political developments that affect the modern day roles and functions of the social worker in the school setting, and covers the types of students served, resources and knowledge needed to deliver services and an overview of the public school system. This course is required for Tennessee state certification as a school social worker. On demand. Prerequisites: SOCW 3060 and SOCW 3120 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Integrative Field Seminar II
prerequisites: SOCW 4070 , SOCW 4120 , SOCW 4130 and SOCW 4170
description: Integrative Field Seminar II is the companion course to be taken in conjunction with the Field Education II course. This course explores on-going practice concerns in the field practicum and creates an arena in which peer learning takes place. Thus, it provides a vital link between the theoretical knowledge, skills, and values derived from the social work course work and the practice realities of the field practicum.Spring semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 4070 , SOCW 4120 , SOCW 4130 and SOCW 4170 . Students must earn “B” or better in SOCW 4130 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Field Education II
prerequisites: SOCW 4120 and SOCW 4130 with a minmum grade of B or Department Head approval
description: This is the second course of the two-part Field Education experience. The course provides an extensive opportunity for students to apply practice theory to develop skills for generalist social work practice. Through active participation in the social service delivery system, the student becomes familiar with agency structures, functions, and programs. Students are required to complete a minimum of 16 hours per week in an agency setting to accrue a total of 200 hours for the semester. Students will also develop and complete the comprehensive Field Learning Agreement to document their successful application of social work competencies and practice behaviors. Prerequisites: SOCW 4120 and SOCW 4130 with a minmum grade of B or Department Head approval. Corequisites: SOCW 4410 . Open to Social Work majors only.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Crisis Intervention & Trauma Skills
prerequisites: Any social work, psychology, anthropology or sociology course.
description: This elective course examines the phenomena of various types of individual, group, and societal level crises, as well as various treatment modalities and emergency interventions appropriate for undergraduate social workers. This course will introduce students to various types of crisis situations, identify research and knowledge needed to intervene in crisis situations, and teach students practice skills for immediate intervention. Potential topics may include but are not limited to suicide and homicide, family or community violence, sexual assault, mental health crises, death, and natural disasters. Summer and Fall semesters. Prerequisites: Any social work, psychology, anthropology or sociology course.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Social Work Practice with Aging Families
prerequisites: SOCW 1100 and SOC 1510 or PSY 1010 or ANTH 1200 or Department Head approval.
description: An overview of social work knowledge, skills, and values applicable to working with older adults and their families. Content includes an examination of theories and attitudes toward aging, the nature and limitations of gerontological social work forces shaping the delivery system, major biopsychological dimensions in practice, and different models of intervention. Spring semester. Prerequisites: SOCW 1100 and SOC 1510 or PSY 1010 or ANTH 1200 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Data Analysis
prerequisites: SOCW 3760 and SOCW 4170 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval
description: This is the final research course in the social work program. In this course, students will complete the research project initiated in the previous semester, as well as complete a series of in-class lab assignments designed to reinforce basic statistical skills. To finalize their research projects, students will finish collecting data, prepare data for analysis, analyze research data, and prepare a final research manuscript. In addition to guidance on the senior research project, this course provides instruction on using SPSS (a statistical software package), solving statistical problems, analyzing data, and interpreting analysis results. Different types of statistical tests and analysis are covered in this course. Students will participate in a formal research showcase to present their research project and findings. Prerequisites: SOCW 3760 and SOCW 4170 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval. Social Work course fee will be assessed.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SOCW
title: Senior Seminar
prerequisites: SOCW 4070 , SOCW 4120 , SOCW 4130 and SOCW 4170 or Department Head approval.
description: The Senior Seminar is designed to engage students in advance learning activities that integrate information from the social work curriculum. Students will demonstrate a readiness for practice evidenced by mastery in social work competency areas with an emphasis on evaluation of practice. Students will present themselves as emerging professionals and leaders in the profession in their ability to apply their knowledge and skills in practice. Prerequisites: SOCW 4070 , SOCW 4120 , SOCW 4130 and SOCW 4170 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

description: In this course students continue to master skills in Spanish at the intermediate level, such as speaking and writing proficiency, and listening and reading comprehension, with an emphasis on the unique cultures of the Hispanic world. Fall and Spring semesters.Prerequisites: SPAN 2110 with a minimum grade of C or placement, or Department Head approval. Students may not take SPAN 2140 and SPAN 2120 for credit without department head approval. General Education Category: Individual and Global Citizenship or Humanities and Fine Arts
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish for Reading I
prerequisites: SPAN 1020 with a minimum grade of C or placement or Department Head approval.
description: Continuation of grammar, and oral practice in Spanish with emphasis in acquiring reading skills. Classes taught mostly in English with discussion in Spanish or in English. This course is for students who only wish to satisfy their foreign language requirement. It does not prepare students for upper level Spanish courses. Fall semester. Prerequisites: SPAN 1020 with a minimum grade of C or placement or Department Head approval.

description: Readings on Hispanic culture, literature and civilization. Emphasis on acquiring reading and translation skills. Classes conducted mostly in Spanish with discussion in English or in Spanish. This course is for students who only wish to satisfy their foreign language requirement. It does not prepare students for upper level Spanish courses. Spring semester. Prerequisites: SPAN 2110 or SPAN 2130 with a minimum grade of C or placement or Department Head approval.

description: Selections from Spanish cinema, literature, topics of current interest, and articles from Spanish newspapers and magazines may be used as a basis for discussions and compositions. Fall semester. description: Selections from Spanish short stories, topics of current interest, and articles from Spanish newspapers and magazines may be used as a basis for discussions and compositions. subject: SPAN
title: Introduction to Literature
prerequisites: SPAN 2120 with a minimum grade of C or placement out of the first two years of Spanish, or Department Head approval.
description: This course is designed in order to introduce students to the study of textual analysis in Spanish and to improve analytical writing skills in the target language. By approaching textual analysis in terms of genre–namely narrative fiction, essay, poetry, and drama–students will develop an understanding of specific generic conventions, along with an appreciation of broader themes and trends in Hispanic literature and culture. This course is also designed to promote critical thinking skills; thus, students will learn how to interpret, discuss, and write analytical essays about different kinds of texts in Spanish. On demand. Prerequisites: SPAN 2120 with a minimum grade of C or placement out of the first two years of Spanish, or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SPAN
title: Advanced Spanish I
prerequisites: SPAN 2120 with a minimum grade of C or placement, or Department Head approval.
description: Study of advanced grammar with special emphasis on writing and style. Reading and analysis of illustrative texts. Practice may be in a variety of written genres and styles: creative writing, persuasive essays, research papers, technical writing, translation or editing. On demand. Prerequisites: SPAN 2120 with a minimum grade of C or placement, or Department Head approval.

subject: SPAN
title: Advanced Conversation
prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or Department Head approval.
description: This course is designed to improve foreign-language speaking skills through conversation practice with native informants or professors and critical reflections. The course may be repeated a total of 3 times for a maximum of 3 credit hours (students who repeat the course will be given more advanced conversation assignments). This course is limited to students majoring in modern foreign languages. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or Department Head approval.

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish for the Professions
prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 or SPAN 4050 or SPAN 4060 with a grade of C or better or Department Head approval
corequisites: At least one additional 3000-level class beyond prerequisites or Department Head approval.
pre_or_corequisites: At least one additional 3000-level class beyond prerequisites or Department Head approval.
description: This course teaches specific terminology and practices associated with professions like the medical field, the criminal justice system, and business, as well as Hispanic professional culture. On demand. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 or SPAN 4050 or SPAN 4060 with a grade of C or better or Department Head approval. Pre or Corequisites: At least one additional 3000-level class beyond prerequisites or Department Head approval.

description: This course is designed to help students develop their Spanish language skills for use in the medical profession. Students will learn medical vocabulary and grammar, as well as cultural competence in the context of health care. Spring semester. Prerequisites: SPAN 2120 with a grade of C or placement exam or Department Head approval.

prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 , and SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , and SPAN 3130 , or Department Head approval.
description: Study of topics such as Spanish-American novel, Spanish-American theater and poetry, and Spanish-American essay. On demand, by special arrangement with the department head and the instructor. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 , and SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , and SPAN 3130 , or Department Head approval.

subject: SPAN
title: Cervantes: Don Quijote de la Mancha
prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 , and SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , and SPAN 3130 , or Department Head approval.
description: A critical reading of Cervantes’ masterpiece, in its entirety, in the original seventeenth-century Spanish. The history, art, philosophy, religion, and literature of Spanish Golden Age, presented as the background for Cervantes’ novellas. The imprint of Cervantes’ prose style in modern Spanish will be studied. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 , and SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , and SPAN 3130 , or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SPAN
title: Romance Philology
prerequisites: FREN 3210 or FREN 3220 , or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , or LAT 2020 , or Department Head approval.
description: Historical linguistics, the development of Romance languages from Vulgar Latin into modern Romance Languages. Covers basic linguistic concepts and terminology as well as phonological and morphological developments in Romance languages with particular emphasis in French and Spanish. Prerequisites: FREN 3210 or FREN 3220 , or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , or LAT 2020 , or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SPAN
title: Spanish Internship for Teachers
prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 , and SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , and SPAN 3130 , or Department Head approval.
description: This course is an intensive internship for teachers. It includes a cooperative arrangement between the student and educational, business or social service agencies involved with foreign languages. Students who seek licensure in modern languages are required to study abroad or have a similar cultural experience. This meets the requirement for that experience. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 , and SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 , and SPAN 3130 , or Department Head approval.

subject: SPAN
title: Translation Studies
prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 or SPAN 4030 or SPAN 4060 and an additional 3000 - or 4000 level Spanish class with a C or better or Department Head approval.
description: This course is an introduction to the theory, methods, techniques, and practice of English to Spanish translation and Spanish to English translation. Students will learn the fundamentals of translating general material from different fields. Students will be able to contrast writing styles and grammar structures in Spanish and English. On demand. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 or SPAN 4030 or SPAN 4060 and an additional 3000 - or 4000 level Spanish class with a C or better or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: SPAN
title: Interpretation Studies
prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 or SPAN 4050 or SPAN 4060 and an additional 3000 - or 4000 level Spanish class with a grade of C or better or Department Head approval.
description: This course builds the fundamental skills necessary for interpreting from English into Spanish and Spanish into English, while exploring various types of interpretation, the history of interpreting, and special considerations and debates within the field. On demand. Prerequisites: SPAN 3110 or SPAN 3120 or SPAN 3210 or SPAN 3220 or SPAN 4050 or SPAN 4060 and an additional 3000 - or 4000 level Spanish class with a grade of C or better or Department Head approval.

description: This is a variable credit class. The 2-credit course will allow senior-level students to reflect on their experience as majors in Spanish, French and Classics. They will also prepare to enter the professional world and/or graduate school. Those who take the course for 3 credits will meet with faculty members throughout the semester in order to develop a capstone project and will present their work in a public form. Fall and Spring semesters. Pre or Corequisites: SPAN 4000R, SPAN 4010R, SPAN 4020R , SPAN 4030 , SPAN 4060 or Department Head approval.Senior standing. Open to Modern and Classical Literatures and Languages majors only.

subject: STEM
title: Step One/Step Two: Inquiry-Based Mathematics and Science
description: Introduction to mathematics and science teaching as a career. Discussions include standards-based lesson design; various teaching methods designed to meet instructional goals; behavior management strategies; and learner goals. The course emphasizes lesson planning and assessment of student learning. Students develop and teach inquiry-based lessons to students in middle grades and to students in grades three through five, all in local elementary and middle schools, and participate in peer coaching. Field component. Fall and Spring semesters. Lecture 2 hours. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: STEM
title: Special Projects
prerequisites: Department Head approval.
description: Individual or group projects. On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: STEM
title: Knowing and Learning
prerequisites: University, STEM and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; STEM 1030 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education Director approval
description: Course introduces the teacher candidate to the psychological foundations of educational theory and practice especially as it applies to the teaching of mathematics and science. Topics include learning theories and the contributions of leaders in the field of knowing and learning, learner characteristics and diversity, intelligence, motivation, and various models of teaching math and science for all learners. It offers a broad base of content focused on human learning as well as a more in-depth look at how students learn and retain concepts in mathematics and science. Every semester. Prerequisites: University, STEM and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; STEM 1030 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education Director approval. Admission to the STEM Education program.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: STEM
title: Classroom Interactions
prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; STEM 2010 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program Director approval
description: Course introduces the principles behind delivering effective instruction in various formats (lecture, lab, digital, cooperative settings); examination of gender, class, race, and culture in mathematics and science education; basics of exceptional education policies and practices; and overview of policy related to mathematics and science education. Field component. Every semester. Prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; STEM 2010 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program Director approval. Admission to the STEM Education program. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: STEM
title: Group Studies

description: On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval. Department may have additional prerequisite requirements.

subject: STEM
title: Perspectives on Science and Mathematics
prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; ENGL 1020 or UHON 1020 and completion of all 1000-level major courses with a minimum grade of C; STEM 2020 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program director approval
description: Introduction to the historical, social and philosophical implications of the nature of science/mathematics and how to integrate this information into the curriculum to enhance learning. Emphasis will be placed on assessment techniques and developmentally appropriate strategies and materials. Classroom diagnostic and prescriptive teaching; linking secondary science and mathematics, assessment, decision-making and instruction; in-depth study of selected assessment instruments, instructional strategies, materials, and management procedures in science and mathematics education. Students are also expected to demonstrate a vision of scientific literacy that connects theory to practice. Every semester. Prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; ENGL 1020 or UHON 1020 and completion of all 1000-level major courses with a minimum grade of C; STEM 2020 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program director approval. Admission to the STEM Education program.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: STEM
title: Research Methods in Science
prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; ENGL 1020 or UHON 1020 , an approved general education statistics course and completion of all 1000-level major courses with a minimum grade of C; STEM 2020 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program Director approval
description: Recent developments and research methods in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. Students perform independent inquiries and learn to combine skills from STEM to solve research problems. Every semester. Prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; ENGL 1020 or UHON 1020 , an approved general education statistics course and completion of all 1000-level major courses with a minimum grade of C; STEM 2020 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program Director approval. Admission to the STEM Education program. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed.

title: Project-Based Instruction
prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; STEM 3020 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program director approval
description: Foundations of project-based, case-based, and problem-based learning environments; principles of project-based curriculum development in mathematics and science education; classroom management and organization of project- based learning classrooms. Field component. Fall and Spring semesters. Lecture 3 hours. Prerequisites: University, STEM, and major department grade point averages of at least 2.75; STEM 3020 with a minimum grade of C or STEM Education program director approval. Admission to the STEM Education program.

subject: STEM
title: Apprentice Teaching
prerequisites: STEM 4010 with a minimum grade of C
description: Closely supervised fieldwork in cooperating school. Experience includes carrying out the duties of a secondary teacher. Twenty to 40 hours of fieldwork per week. Students will enroll in 10 credit hours according to the details of their field component. Field component. Fall and Spring semesters. Prerequisites: STEM 4010 with a minimum grade of C. Successful completion of Checkpoint 3 and all but at most two content courses successfully completed and a passing score on preliminary portfolio or Department Head approval. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed. Satisfactory/No Credit.

description: A study of the theatre and its drama; examination of selected plays as representative types of drama, as products of a cultural milieu, and as works intended for performance. Designed to heighten the student’s perception, appreciation, and enjoyment of a variety of forms of theatre in performance. Every semester. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed. General Education Category: Humanities and Fine Arts

description: Introduction to the principles and practices of designing theatrical environments and costumes for plays. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed.

subject: THSP
title: Performance and Production
description: Lower division laboratory course in all aspects of theatre performance and production. Project assignments in departmental productions and workshops. May be repeated for credit. Every semester. Must be a Theatre major or minor. Laboratory/studio course fee will be assessed.

title: Voice and Body
description: A studio class that provides a basic physical and vocal warmup for auditions, rehearsals, and performances. Fall semester. Must be a theatre major or minor. Production course fee applies.

subject: THSP
title: Interpersonal Communication
description: Examination of the basic theories and practices of face-to-face communication: how communication messages are designed, produced, exchanged, and interpreted in a variety of interpersonal contexts. Practical exercises in speech communication will be required. On demand.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

description: Fundamentals of acting and of speech for the theatre. Fall semester. Must be a Theatre major or minor, or Department Head approval.

title: Dance Technique II

source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga24.pdf

subject: THSP
title: War Atrocities in Film
description: Through selected films and their use of cinematic elements to reveal atrocities, students will study both international and American examples and assess what led up to these heinous actions. Students will analyze both fiction and non- fiction films, assessing their effectiveness through research of these films’ critical reception and the student’s own aesthetic judgment.

description: Introduction to Grand Challenges Seminar introduces students to the Grand Challenges Scholars and helps students determine (1) if the program is for them and (2) what challenge they may want to address during their academic career here at UTC. Invited speakers and introductions to research and project opportunities included. Students may retake this seminar if their application for GCSP is not complete or not accepted. Fall and Spring semesters. Admissions to the Honors College or approval from the Associate Dean. Satisfactory/No Credit.

subject: UHON
title: Junior Honors Studies
description: An introduction to developing sustained programs for research and/or creative activity, in preparation for proposing a Departmental Honors or Honors College thesis. Through workshops and discussion, students will extend their knowledge of library resources, topic development and focus, thesis advisor and committee selection, proposal writing, and project scheduling. Required of Honors College students in the semester prior to submitting a thesis proposal. Fall and Spring semesters. Open to UTC students eligible to undertake Departmental Honors.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: UHON
title: Topics in Humanities and Fine Arts
description: Students will critically interpret the works, products, and developments in artistic and humanistic fields, assess the cultural and historical significance of these works, and apply appropriate disciplinary vocabulary for artistic and humanistic fields of study. Specific topics to be listed in the class schedule. May be repeated with different content for a maximum credit of 12 hours. Limited to Honors College students; others with approval of the Associate Dean of the Honors College. General Education Category: Humanities and Fine Arts
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: UHON
title: Topics in Natural Science
gened_category_text: Natural Science Lecture or Natural Science Lecture/Lab
description: Students will explain how scientific knowledge develops over time, demonstrate scientific literacy, and explain how scientific developments impact society. Corequisite lab courses will also demonstrate the connection between scientific theory and application and apply the methods of science. Specific topics to be listed in the class schedule. May be repeated with different content for a maximum credit of 7-8 hours.Limited to Honors College students; others with approval of the Associate Dean of the Honors College. General Education Category: Natural Science Lecture or Natural Science Lecture/Lab
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: UHON
title: Topics in Behavioral and Social Sciences
description: Students will explain behavioral and social phenomena, institutions, systems, or processes, and the importance of understanding how the diversity of human experiences and belief systems are shaped by human institutions and practices. Students will also evaluate how data, concepts, or methods within the discipline are used to support conclusions about individual, group, or institutional behavior. Specific topics to be listed in the class schedule. May be repeated with different content for a maximum credit of 6 hours.Limited to Honors College students; others with approval of the Associate Dean of the Honors College. General Education Category: Behavioral and Social Science
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: UHON
title: Topics in Quantitative Reasoning
description: Students will interpret, present, and communicate quantitative information presented in mathematical and/or statistical forms as well as evaluate quantitative evidence and assumptions using quantitative tools and technologies to make judgments and draw conclusions about problems in personal, professional, and public life. Specific topics to be listed in the class schedule. May be repeated with different content for a maximum credit of 6- 7 hours. Lecture 3 hours; laboratory 1 hour. Limited to Honors College students; others with approval of the Associate Dean of the Honors College. General Education Category: Quantitative Reasoning
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: UHON
title: Topics in Individual and Global Citizenship
description: Students will assess how multiple perspectives and experiences, especially those previously underrepresented historically and currently, manifest in societies. By applying conceptual/theoretical frameworks to issues on a local, regional, national, and/or global scale, students will understand how overlapping experiences affect people individually and as groups, and they will demonstrate intercultural knowledge/competencies and a sense of community through interaction with the cultural, material, spatial, and/or historical dimensions of the world around us. Specific topics to be listed in the class schedule. May be repeated for purposes of the honors minors.Limited to Honors College students; others with approval of the Associate Dean of the Honors College. General Education Category: Individual and Global Citizenship
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: UHON
title: Continuing in Grand Challenges Seminar
description: Continuing in Grand Challenges Seminar provides advising and other support to students as they progress on their Grand Challenges Scholars Program (GCSP) journey. Students will (1) manage their competencies path, (2) begin building their GCSP Portfolio, (3) find or build a relationship with a mentor to progress with the GCSP project or research, and (4) receive instruction on completing the GCSP thesis. Invited speakers and research and project opportunity emphasis included. Students participate in this seminar every semester they are in the GCSP program after the semester in Introduction to Grand Challenges Seminar. Fall and Spring semesters. Admissions to the Honors College or approval from the Associate Dean. Satisfactory/No Credit.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

A maximum of six credit hours may be earned in UHON 3950r, with no more than three hours earned per semester. Every semester. Prerequisites: Approved internship proposal. Open to Honors College students only. Satisfactory/No Credit.

subject: USTU
title: Academic Coaching: Student Success Strategies
description: Academic Coaching: Student Success Strategies (1 credit hour) is a course designed for first-year students who want to improve upon the development of skill sets related to academic success. The purpose of the course is to teach Metacognitive Learning Strategies for academic success, to assist students in developing a growth mindset, creating an individualized study plan and learning how to function at higher levels of understanding as described in Bloom’s Taxonomy. As a result of enrolling in this course, students will learn skills needed to be successful in higher education. Students enrolled in this course will earn one hour of graded, elective credit. Fall semester.

The purpose of the course is to teach Metacognitive Learning Strategies for academic success and to develop strategies for Motivation, Initiative, Direction, and Time Management. As a result of enrolling in this course, students will learn skills needed to be successful in college. Students enrolled in this course will earn one hour of graded, elective credit. subject: USTU
title: Arts Integration
prerequisites: EDUC 3060, EDUC 3230 or PDS I, and two courses from ART 3010 , MUS 1110 and THSP 1150 or Department Head approval.
description: Designed for pre-service education majors as an introduction to the philosophy and practice of arts integration. This course will provide students with basic knowledge of educational drama, dance, music and visual art, clear reasons for integration, specific integration principles applicable across the curriculum, and ongoing opportunities to develop, observe, lead and participate in arts integration instruction in elementary classrooms. Prerequisites: EDUC 3060, EDUC 3230 or PDS I, and two courses from ART 3010 , MUS 1110 and THSP 1150 or Department Head approval.

subject: WGSS
title: Introduction to Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies
gened_category_text: Individual and Global Citizenship or Behavioral and Social Science
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval
description: An examination of human experience from a feminist perspective. An exploration of the ways in which women have been defined and have defined themselves. A multi-disciplinary teaching context with focus on women’s self identity, women’s identity in families, and women’s identity in society. Prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval. General Education Category: Individual and Global Citizenship or Behavioral and Social Science
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women’s Issues in South Asia
description: A survey of contemporary issues for women in South Asia. On demand.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women’s Health Issues
gened_category_text: Individual and Global Citizenship or Behavioral and Social Science
prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval
description: A review of current literature and discussion of issues affecting contemporary women’s health. The course will introduce the biological, psychological, social, economic, and cultural factors which affect the health of women. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval. Open to non-majors. General Education Category: Individual and Global Citizenship or Behavioral and Social Science
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Popular Fiction
description: Science fiction or detective fiction or other type of popular fiction, one or another of which will be studied for its literary merit: the type of popular fiction to be studied in any particular section will be specified in the schedule of classes. On demand. May be registered as ENGL 2510R. Effective Spring 2026.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Read, Write, Respawn
description: In this course, students will engage rhetorical theory and/or literary theory to analyze and create both traditional texts and video games. Fall and Spring semesters. May be registered as ENGL 2550. Effective Spring 2026.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Gender Based Violence
description: Examines a variety of forms of violence against women in the United States including domestic violence, sexual assault, sexual harassment and pornography. Explores how violence against women has been minimized in society and how the criminal justice system has rarely developed effective ways to address these types of crimes. May be registered as CRMJ 2950 . Credit not allowed in both CRMJ 2950 and WGSS 2950. General Education Category: Behavioral and Social Science
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Group Studies
prerequisites: Department Head approval
description: On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval. Department may have additional prerequisite requirements.

subject: WGSS
title: Latin American Women Writers in Translation
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or ENGL 1020 or UHON 1010 or UHON 1020 or Department Head approval
description: Contributions of Latin American women writers to the social, economic, and political institutions of Latin American culture. Readings from literary selections in several genres. Topics will include gender roles, systems of authority, masculine/feminine representations of reality, and the concept of “feminine” writing. No foreign language credit. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or ENGL 1020 or UHON 1010 or UHON 1020 or Department Head approval. May be registered as MLNG 3020. Credit not allowed in both MLNG 3020 and WGSS 3020.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Society
prerequisites: SOC 1150 or SOC 1510 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval
description: Analysis of how ideas about gender are socially constructed and the importance of women-centered theories on this approach; the interplay of gender and various social structures including education, religion, politics, family, health, work and sexuality. Prerequisites: SOC 1150 or SOC 1510 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval. May be registered as SOC 3070 . Credit not allowed in both SOC 3070 and WGSS 3070.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Criminal Justice
prerequisites: CRMJ 1100 or completion of social science general education requirement or Department Head approval
description: This course is intended to provide an overview of women’s involvement in the criminal justice system as offenders, victims and professionals. Considerable attention will be given to women as victims of crime, the social system and the criminal justice process. On demand. Prerequisites: CRMJ 1100 or completion of social science general education requirement or Department Head approval. May be registered as CRMJ 3180 . Credit not allowed in both CRMJ 3180 and WGSS 3180.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: American Women Writers
prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval
description: A survey of American women writers of the 20th century. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval. May be registered as ENGL 3210. Credit not allowed in both ENGL 3210 and WGSS 3210.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Race, Gender and the Media
prerequisites: Department Head approval
description: Examines U.S. mass media construction of race, ethnicity, gender, and sexuality within an historical context and investigates the role of women and minority groups in U.S. media industries. On demand. Lecture 3 hours. Prerequisites: Department Head approval. Junior standing. May be registered as COMM 3240 . Credit not allowed in both COMM 3240 and WGSS 3240.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Economics of Gender, Race and Inequality
prerequisites: ECON 1020 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval.Junior standing
description: This course will explore how inequality is measured in society, its primary economic drivers, and its ultimate consequences. Outcome differences in variables such as education, employment, income, and wealth, will be measured across gender, race, nationality, and sexual orientation. How individual’s choices, constraints, and subjected discrimination can affect their economic outcomes will be analyzed. The effectiveness of both market and public policy approaches at eliminating inequality, such as anti-discrimination laws, taxes and redistribution, and investment policies are assessed. On demand. Lecture 3 hours.Prerequisites: ECON 1020 with a minimum grade of C or Department Head approval.Junior standing. May be registered as ECON 3270 . Credit not allowed in both ECON 3270 and WGSS 3270.Differential course fee will be assessed.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Gender in Politics
description: An examination of the role and status of women in the American political system. Special emphasis given to the impact of selected public policies upon women. On demand. May be registered as PSPS 3230 . Credit not allowed in both PSPS 3230 and WGSS 3360. Effective Spring 2026.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Psychology of Human Sexuality
prerequisites: 6 hours of Psychology credits OR 6 hours of Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies credits or Department Head approval
description: This course will introduce the study of human sexuality. Specifically, this course investigates human sexuality from biological and psychological perspectives. We will study male, female, and intersex sexual anatomy; sexual arousal, sexual response, and behaviors; gender identity and sexual orientation; and communication in relationships. In addition, we will study contraception, sexual infections, sexual difficulties/dysfunction, atypical sexual behavior, and healthy relationships and sexual violence. To promote our understanding of these topics, we will study the methodology available to investigate human sexuality. Prerequisites: 6 hours of Psychology credits OR 6 hours of Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies credits or Department Head approval. Also offered as PSY 3370. Credit not allowed in both PSY 3370 and WGSS 3370.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: American Sexual Histories
description: An examination of shifting perceptions of gender and sexuality over the course of United States history. Topics include ideas about interracial romance, sex censorship, the eugenics movement, the development of LGBT identities, shifting marital and familial norms and the development of feminist thought. May be registered as HIST 3420 . Credit not allowed in both WGSS 3420 and HIST 3420 .
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Queer American History
description: While terms like gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, and intersex have relatively recent origins, the contemporary LGBTQ+ community has deep historical roots in America. Spanning from the seventeenth century to the present, this course explores the past experiences of individuals and groups who would be categorized today under the LGBTQ+ umbrella. It examines the long history of protest and political action that sexual minorities have undertaken in pursuit of civil rights and social justice, as well as the consistent legal and cultural backlash that has accompanied LGBTQ+ visibility. As we shift our focus from decade to decade, we will observe the ever-evolving ideas about what was “natural” and “normal” when it came to gender and sexual identity, and we will consider the many social forces shaping popular opinion on sexual matters (e.g. the press, lawmakers, scientists, religious figures, authors, filmmakers, etc.). Throughout the semester we will examine queer history within an intersectional framework; that is to say, we will contemplate the wide array of identities that constituted our subjects’ lived experiences, including race, ethnicity, nationality, class, gender, sex, sexual orientation, religion, and region. As we shall see, there has not been one uniform queer experience in the United States. Rather, there are countless factors that have shaped the lives of queer Americans throughout the centuries. This class will give students an opportunity to learn about some of these experiences, and to consider the methods that historians might use to uncover those queer histories that have yet to be told. Lecture 3 hours. May be registered as HIST 3425. No credit in both HIST 3425 and WGSS 3425.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: British Women Writers
prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval
description: A survey of British women writers with an eye to traditions, themes, and styles. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval. May be registered as ENGL 3450 . Credit not allowed in both WGSS 3450 and ENGL 3450 .
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Group Studies
prerequisites: Department Head approval
description: On demand. Prerequisites: Department Head approval. Department may have additional prerequisite requirements.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Theatre and Feminism
prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or UHON 1020 or Department Head approval
description: Readings, discussion and writing about a wide variety of plays by modern feminist playwrights. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or UHON 1020 or Department Head approval. May be registered as ENGL 4020 or THSP 4020 . Credit allowed in only one of the three courses.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women, Gender, and Power in European History
description: A survey of the history of women and gender in medieval and early modern Europe. Topics will include pre-modern ideas about gender and women; gender in European empires; women’s role in and relationship to religion; men’s and women’s positions within the household; the regulation of sexuality; and the emergence of women’s rights. May be registered as HIST 4150 . Credit not allowed in both HIST 4150 and WGSS 4150.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Sexuality in Religion
description: How do ideas about gender and sexuality offer new ways to understand religion, society, and culture? In this course we explore the diversity of sexual difference in context of contemporary global religions, especially Islam, Hinduism, and Buddhism. Course themes include: the tension between theory and practice, authority and gender, women’s lives, masculinities, gender fluidity, and the role of the nation in constructing gender and sexuality in religious communities. The course approach is interdisciplinary and includes readings from religious primary sources, history, anthropology, and literature. May be registered as REL 4160. Credit not allowed in both REL 4160 and WGSS 4160.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Technologies of Sex and Gender
prerequisites: SOC 1510 , SOC 2230 , ANTH 1100 , or WGSS 2000 or Department Head approval
description: Synthesizing and applying sociological theories of technology, gender, and sexualities, this course explores how gender and sexuality are shaped by technology and science, affecting individual, group, and institutional norms, behaviors and processes. Salient topics such as digitized intimacy, gendered and sexual technoscience, and application of Artificial Intelligence to gendered processes will be examined through contemporary empirical research. Fall or Spring semester. Prerequisites: SOC 1510 , SOC 2230 , ANTH 1100 , or WGSS 2000 or Department Head approval. May be registered as SOC 4230 or WGSS 4230. Effective Spring 2026.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Gender and Law
prerequisites: PSPS 3000 or Department Head approval
description: An examination of the development of the legal definitions of gender in the United States, specifically centering on the tensions that occur in a democratic system when disenfranchised groups seek power, with attention to the role that the law and legal structures play in the pursuit of equality. Prerequisites: PSPS 3000 or Department Head approval. May be registered as PSPS 4310 . Credit not allowed in both PSPS 4310 and WGSS 4310.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Psychology of Men and Masculinities
prerequisites: 6 hours of Psychology credits OR 6 hours of Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies credits or Department Head approval
description: This course centers on the lived experiences of men and boys. This course explores diverse theoretical models (i.e., biopsychosocial models, feminist perspectives, intersectional frameworks) on the development and psychological experiences of men/masculinity. This course also discusses psychological experiences and outcomes of men and masculinity as they relate to topics such as mental and physical health, relationships, parenting, sexuality, and violence and aggression. This course will also introduce perspectives on avenues for social change. Prerequisites: 6 hours of Psychology credits OR 6 hours of Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies credits or Department Head approval. May be registered as PSY 4420. Credit not allowed in both PSY 4420 and WGSS 4420.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Black Women Writers
description: Study of black women’s writing from the eighteenth century to the present day. Emphasis will be placed on historical, black feminist, and/or Africana womanist approaches to women’s literature of the African diaspora. Junior or Senior standing or director approval. May be registered as ENGL 4440. Credit not allowed in both ENGL 4440 and WGSS 4440.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Major American Figures
description: A reading course in the works of a major American writer or writers. Writers to be studied will be specified in the schedule of classes. Maximum credit 6 hours for the degree. On demand. May be registered as ENGL 4270R only when the content focuses on female authors.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Fiction, Fashion and Feminism
prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval (program head for the WGSS section)
description: An examination of how garments, styles, and fabric function in literary texts. Prerequisites: ENGL 1020 or Department Head approval (program head for the WGSS section). May be registered as ENGL 4500 . Credit not allowed in both ENGL 4500 and WGSS 4500.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Psychology of Women
prerequisites: 6 hours of psychology and or Department Head approval
description: Analysis of empirical data and theoretical viewpoints concerning the psychological development of women. Psychological effects of sex roles, achievement motivation, and abilities of women; models of socialization practices, personality development, and stages of adjustment. Fall semester. Prerequisites: 6 hours of psychology and or Department Head approval. Junior standing. May be registered as PSY 4510 . Credit not allowed in both PSY 4510 and WGSS 4510.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Topics in Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval.
description: Specific topics, themes and subjects related to women, gender and sexuality studies. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women and Textiles
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or Department Head approval.
description: A study of women’s role in textile production as laborers, master crafters, consumers, and artists. Prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Ecofeminism
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval.
description: The study of the intersection of feminist issues and environmental issues. Prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Literary Criticism
prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval
description: The history, theory and practice of feminist literary criticism studied in cultural context. Prerequisites: ENGL 1010 or ENGL 1011 or UHON 1010 or Department Head approval. May be registered as ENGL 4710 . No credit in both ENGL 4710 and WGSS 4710.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Feminist Theory
description: A history of feminist theory from the eighteenth century to the present. Extensive reading, papers. Maybe registered as HUM 4830 or PHIL 4830 . Credit allowed in only one of the three courses.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women’s Rhetoric
prerequisites: ENGL 1020 and ENGL 2050 , or Department Head approval
description: A theoretical, historical, and, primarily, rhetorical examination of women’s discourse through the study of speeches, essays, and other rhetorical artifacts. Special attention will be given to the ways women have used traditional rhetorical strategies and how they have subverted this tradition and/or brought strategies from private life to bear on public discourses. On demand. Prerequisites: ENGL 1020 and ENGL 2050 , or Department Head approval. May be registered as ENGL 4850 . Credit not allowed in both ENGL 4850 and WGSS 4850.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Queer Theory
description: A theoretical, historical, and textual look at the intersection of discourses of sexuality and literary and rhetorical analysis. Emphasis will be placed on understanding a broad history and narrative of queer politics and culture. Spring semester. May be registered as ENGL 4885 . No credit in both WGSS 4885 and ENGL 4885 .
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Women’s Studies Internship
prerequisites: 15 hours of WGSS courses and approval of Director of Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies and a 3.0 overall GPA and a 2.5 overall GPA.
description: 120-150 hours of hands-on experience with an appropriate company agency or nonprofit. Students must apply for the internship during the semester prior to that of the intended internship experience. Prerequisites: 15 hours of WGSS courses and approval of Director of Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies and a 3.0 overall GPA and a 2.5 overall GPA.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf

subject: WGSS
title: Senior Seminar
prerequisites: approval of coordinator or Department Head approval
description: Senior seminar for women’s studies majors that comprises directed readings, presentations, and discussions that will inform a supervised research paper or a service learning project appropriate to the student’s area of interest and experience. Prerequisites: approval of coordinator or Department Head approval. Senior standing.
source_doc: Course Descriptions - University of Tennessee, Chattanooga25.pdf
